proposition: Free trade agreements benefit workers in all participating countries

In developed countries, free trade encourages industries to specialize in what they do best, driving innovation and productivity. This specialization leads to higher value jobs in sectors where a country has a competitive advantage. For instance, the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) helped Canada and the U.S. strengthen their manufacturing and technology sectors, leading to well-paying jobs and improved working conditions.

In developing countries, free trade agreements open up access to larger markets, which spurs investment and infrastructure development. This investment creates employment in a variety of sectors, from manufacturing to services. For example, Vietnam's integration into global trade through agreements like the U.S.-Vietnam Bilateral Trade Agreement significantly reduced poverty and lifted millions into the middle class by creating jobs in textiles, agriculture, and technology.

Moreover, free trade promotes labor standards. When countries are part of international trade agreements, they are more likely to adopt and enforce labor laws to remain competitive and maintain their access to global markets. This results in safer working conditions, fair wages, and reduced child labor in many parts of the world.

In summary, free trade agreements lead to more jobs, higher wages, and better working conditions for workers in all participating countries. The benefits are widespread and long-lasting, as open trade fosters economic development and prosperity.
